meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny -

I'm back with another review, this time taking a swing (pun intended) at Big Ant Studios' Cricket 24. Now, I know what you're thinking - cricket? Really? But trust me, folks, this game is worth more than just a casual glance. And don't worry if you're not familiar with the sport; my review will be as smooth as a perfectly placed cover drive (see what I did there?).

First off, let's get to those critics' reviews. IGN gave it a lackluster 50, calling it "a bit too inconsistent overall" and saying that it needs some post-release tweaking to really shine. Digitally Downloaded was more optimistic, praising the game for its excellent ball-to-ball action, but lamenting that it still doesn't quite capture the nuances of the sport. Push Square panned it, stating that Cricket 24 fails to build upon previous instalments in a significant way and is plagued by bugs and glitches. VideoGamer thought it had potential if it could capture the essence of its new licenses, while GamingBolt said it builds on its predecessor but could have used more fine-tuning. Press Start Australia gave it a mixed bag review, praising the gameplay but criticizing the visual fidelity and polish. And Stevivor? Well, they just wished for a bit more innovation from Big Ant Studios.

Now, onto my thoughts! I've played Cricket 24, and while it's not without its flaws, there are some definite positives to take away. The gameplay is fun - I mean, who doesn't love smashing sixes or cleverly rotating the strike? The different bowling and batting styles add a nice layer of depth for those looking to dive deeper into the series. And let's not forget those licensed modes; reliving the 20XX Ashes or forging a lengthy career are definite highlights.

However, I do agree with some critics that Cricket 24 feels like more of an incremental update rather than a significant leap forward. The visuals and presentation could be polished, and there are moments where it feels like you're watching a replay during a rain delay (ahem, Stevivor's phrase).

All in all, Cricket 24 is a solid addition to the series, but it may not be enough to lure in those who have already played past instalments. For new players, though? It remains as accessible and enjoyable as a sport can be. So, what do I recommend?

If you're looking for a fun, if not groundbreaking, cricket experience with plenty of licensed modes and gameplay options, Cricket 24 is worth checking out. Just don't expect it to revolutionize the sport or your life (unless you're a massive cricket fan - in which case, this game is already a winner!).

That's all for now, folks! Hippo Penny, signing off...
